content.content: Dear community, With today’s negative yet spectacular vote, with almost 300k MKRs participating, the idea of creating a financial oversight core unit focused on monitoring and assessing financial risk of complex collateral, comes to an end. This post is not a reflection about the tactical events of the most recent days, that will be done somewhere else by many, but a nice and kind farewell to a project I have dedicated, with many others, several months of sweat and tears. Many, also among the NO voters (at least before the vote for LOVE became a proxy fight for the future of DeFi - whatever that means) have praised my work publicly and privately and also the good intentions of this Core Unit. For this, I am grateful. Those who worked with me over the months know that rather than being a plotter, I am just a fighter. Always have been. Hence I fought for the ratification of this Core Unit notwithstanding the changing times. And what a fight we put on. Those who worked with me over the months know also that beyond my sometimes abrasive tones I am a genuine hard worker and no BS professional, and I hope that by being that I have helped several pockets of this DAO to improve. Do nothing is often less risky in a complex organisation, but definitely not my style of living. This is definitely not the time of a financial oversight core unit in the DAO, but I will always remain a proud member of the community, a contributor, and a collaborator of some shape and form. Not sure what that will be, but I guess it will depend on the evolution of the community itself. Having married the great love of my life after we promised each other never to speak again - and we didn’t for five years - I am too old and experienced to give definitive answer to what the future can be. Life is a repeated game. It is however a farewell to LOVE. And with this short letter, I want to thank fair supporters and opponents, and especially some CU colleagues that have made those last months of LOVE incubation insane yet awesome. In random order. I am missing many and I am sorry. @Retro, @wouter, @juan, @williamr, @Eumenes, @teej, @christiancdpetersen, @Aes, @adcv, @hexonaut, @Nadia, @MarianoDP, @monkey.irish, @Davidutro, @prose11, @LongForWisdom, @August, @SebVentures Do not go gentle into that good night
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is bidding farewell to a financial oversight core unit proposal that was voted down. The post is not a reflection on the tactical events of the vote, but rather a thank you to supporters and opponents of the proposal. The author explains their dedication to the project and their fighting spirit. The author also expresses gratitude to colleagues who worked with them on the proposal. The post does not advertise the proposal, ask for feedback, or ask questions about the proposal.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Timing is everything in life! As it was in your LOVE life, I hope it will be on your side in DeFi in the future! Best of luck!

A complete pity, I have participated in two attempts to form a CU and both were rejected, I know at least what it feels like, there is nothing left but to continue working and continue to form a community and time will allow the work done will allow us to obtain it.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: luca_pro:  This is definitely not the time of a financial oversight core unit in the DAO   I don’t want to kick someone when they’re down, but I just want to float the idea that if you hadn’t been such a prominent figure in the growth pill movement this would have probably just passed like most new CUs. I don’t think this was a vote against lending oversight or a second set of eyes on financial deals. I think this was a vote against a small group of people who are new to the protocol going to a cabal of VCs while actively excluding the community. For months now, rumors of closed meetings and slide decks always preceded each and every “public” information sharing by this group of you and those on the Growth Task Force. Even this upcoming call tomorrow only occurred after an email was circulating from you offering an earlier date to VCs. Trust has been broken over and over and over again, and I hope @Aes @hexonaut and @Hasu understand that they killed their own proposals. The lesson here isn’t that Rune still has a lot of power. It’s that when you look at the votes, people turned to Rune - a known dictator - over what they saw as a betrayal of Maker’s ideals and encroachment by the funds on the DAO’s autonomy, I think you generally do good work. I’ve even heard people who lead the vote against you say privately that you did good work. But the methods that you and your colleagues employed managed to bring together a huge amount of tokens and raise a community outcry. I hope you stick around. But you’ve got to learn to be more inclusive and less exclusive within a DAO. People reacted like this was a hostile coup because it was. Next time try to avoid such obvious special treatment to the funds. Good luck and all that jazz.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal

content.content: Thanks, but let’s try to keep this note with a good vibe - that was the intention. I’m sure there have been mistakes in how many behaved in the DAO, but I am as sure that those have been on both sides. I have been working hard to protect this protocol, and my back is straight. And if you think I’m down, you’re truly mistaken.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Hey @AliceinMKRland - I’ve seen a number of your posts re: “VC cabals” recently and I’d love to connect and hear you out. If you’re interested in a chat, please feel free to DM me on the forums or reach me at [email protected] As BlockTower made public on the LOVE vote, we voted YES precisely because we felt this was a vote for lending oversight and a second set of eyes on financial deals (both in crypto collateral and beyond). I think it’s disingenuous to claim otherwise, despite some who viewed this vote as a proxy war about much more. All said, however, the lack of trust between community members is clearly an issue that needs to be resolved. I think you’ve made some great points and would love to collaborate on some solutions
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
